title: 93% Faster Next.js in Kubernetes
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.platformatic.dev%2F93-faster-nextjs-in-your-kubernetes%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b0303d3e5-f633ea4b-5ad9-4108-a61f-87f3396e029d-000000/J_N9BtMKAY4indlsHczxMCeygmxPEDahIw88u9pmQXc=434
summary: 93% Faster Next.js in (your) Kubernetes (18 minute read) Watt made Next.js 93% faster in K8s (182ms → 11.6ms) by ditching PM2's ~30% IPC tax and letting the Linux kernel distribute connections directly via SO_REUSEPORT. Traditional approaches aren't great because PM2 adds coordination overhead, and single-CPU pods can't self-heal when their event loop gets blocked.

title: How Exchanges Turn Order Books into Distributed Logs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 21 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fquant.engineering%2Fexchange-order-book-distributed-logs.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b0303d3e5-f633ea4b-5ad9-4108-a61f-87f3396e029d-000000/9q9KHTxVfLB8Npi6AvYSKmGGgT6vCmA2rpLJeK2MsCU=434
summary: How Exchanges Turn Order Books into Distributed Logs (21 minute read) Order books are distributed logs of market events. This architecture guarantees fairness through deterministic ordering. Modern exchanges behave like ultra-low-latency log processors. The sequencer defines the timeline, the matching engine reduces that timeline into a book, and replication keeps the log durable without slowing the fast path.

summary: A brief history of specifiers and protocols (5 minute read) Node.js introduced the node: protocol in 2021. Deno intro dude https imports in 2018, and then the npm: protocol in 2022. Deno then introduced package.json support in 2023 and the jsr: protocol in 2024. Also in 2024, Deno started moving away from HTTP imports. The current landscape is a messy state of affairs.

title: Microservices should form a polytree
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fbytesauna.com%2Fpost%2Fmicroservices%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b0303d3e5-f633ea4b-5ad9-4108-a61f-87f3396e029d-000000/te7SY4oUDz00x9g_oJEAXOzoTXjQtFrqZKQeICa4hoc=434
summary: Microservices should form a polytree (5 minute read) To avoid the common complexities and failures of microservices, dependency structures should form a "polytree,” a directed acyclic graph whose underlying undirected graph is a tree, to guarantee clear ownership, predictable behavior, and easier system evolution.

title: How To Reduce Cognitive Load in UX
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2Fhow-reduce-cognitive-load-ux-vitaly-friedman-v0wle%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/0100019b033868b5-c75a9450-f6ab-4878-86e4-7cc3a92580a6-000000/EL4aaWVeAtOGf-Nto2IU5RV52jfN_P-Vx3ciljTdFY0=434
summary: How To Reduce Cognitive Load in UX (11 minute read) Reducing cognitive load in UX isn't about oversimplifying complex interfaces. Expert software must match real-world complexity to be effective. Designers should break tasks into smaller steps, avoid forcing users to remember information across screens, and support decision-making through chunking options and clear labeling. The key is understanding how users actually work with a product rather than judging interfaces by appearance alone.

title: Solana and Base “Twin Contract” Bridge
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F1997763313909092415.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019b03458653-99f1c541-cca2-46fc-8bdb-0fc87fd60deb-000000/xBhXyNMVLWNFuZNzk2A7eguEpGaxNSvTy-uMCCss3M4=434
summary: Solana and Base “Twin Contract” Bridge (3 minute read) The new Solana, Base bridge actually works. Tokens move by a standard lock/mint model on the origin chain, while native tokens are locked (or foreign tokens burned). On the destination chain, native tokens are unlocked (or foreign tokens minted). Any SPL token can get its own deterministic ERC-20 on Base via a factory contract, and Base tokens can likewise be deployed on Solana.

title: The Bubble Is Labor
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdanielmiessler.com%2Fblog%2Fthe-real-bubble-is-human-labor%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b0800a495-6cf89a61-eea1-4ee7-b503-834e8cf6e0fa-000000/nZ_xcKARZ8VglrpHS8cyt_LcX-8A-eSWnTcwAnIFg6g=435
summary: The Bubble Is Labor (4 minute read) Companies only hire people because they can't do all of the work themselves. If every founder could handle all of the tasks themselves, there wouldn't be anywhere near the number of jobs we have today. The only reason the current labor market exists is because there's a group of founders/owners who need help producing their goods and services. title: Why frozen test fixtures are a problem on large projects and how to avoid them
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fradanskoric.com%2Farticles%2Ffrozen-test-fixtures%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b083d999a-f3936cdc-fbaf-4971-83db-628bf95bb4bd-000000/8441dHNhtXFXTnUbIPV35bjfhJ2EsrpRP3FzJl_wMho=434
summary: Why frozen test fixtures are a problem on large projects and how to avoid them (8 minute read) Test fixtures often become "frozen" in large software projects because modifications risk breaking thousands of unrelated tests that make implicit assumptions about the data. title: Durable Streams
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fdurable-streams%2Fdurable-streams%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b083d999a-f3936cdc-fbaf-4971-83db-628bf95bb4bd-000000/FR1RTZFPoFM7wFhvVTgPEPaUr8LIyXKx-a8Qlu0Vias=434
summary: Durable Streams (GitHub Repo) Durable Streams is an open protocol that provides real-time sync to client applications. It supports catch-up reads and live tailing. The protocol works anywhere HTTP works, and it is built on standard HTTP with no custom protocols. Durable Streams is built for production scale. It complements backend streaming systems by reliably streaming data to client applications.

title: Ethereum's Next Frontier is Validator Privacy in the P2P Layer
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F1998143303603163575.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019b0872bef0-a5730955-14ca-4e23-b552-47196c98db59-000000/cnRR17n8_JkaCyvukwrD8YheJcxuEJCxe9tdpFb_HgM=435
summary: Ethereum's Next Frontier is Validator Privacy in the P2P Layer (2 minute read) Making validator networking private and fast requires attestation gossip via an OHTTP-style two-hop relay (breaking the IP and validator link), prioritized meshes using a ZK “proof-of-validator” (sybil-resistant without revealing identity), rate-limiting nullifiers to stop spam, and decoy traffic to hide behavioral patterns.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmistral.ai%2Fnews%2Fdevstral-2-vibe-cli%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/kzdAKJb2GxZBGMzoozP7afR5rwJVHXioIM6o1562VRY=435

The 24B Devstral Small 2 scores 68.0% and runs on consumer hardware. Mistral also launched Vibe CLI, an open-source terminal agent that orchestrates multi-file changes across codebases.

title: How People Use AI at Work
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdejan.ai%2Fblog%2Freport-ai-workplace%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/PW9sPVISXF4fogzTzeZynChJXZJv3PccyJ8scR8gqHk=435
summary: How People Use AI at Work (12 minute read) Professionals use AI for grunt work and first drafts. It is never trusted without supervision. Artists use AI to handle admin work so they have more time for creative work. Researchers find that the time required to fact-check AI output often negates the efficiency gains. The primary barrier to AI adoption is hallucination.

title: 2025: The State of Generative AI in the Enterprise
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 32 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmenlovc.com%2Fperspective%2F2025-the-state-of-generative-ai-in-the-enterprise%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/ssoBxYXE8DBaa6aeFc1GrjoDJeLnZm6OuC1ng7kEiVk=435
summary: 2025: The State of Generative AI in the Enterprise (32 minute read) The shift to enterprise AI is no longer speculative. Enterprise AI is now a $37 billion market. It is the fastest-scaling category in software history. AI is becoming the core of how work gets done across industries, and enterprises, seeing real returns, are doubling down.

title: There is no data-generating distribution
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.argmin.net%2Fp%2Fthere-is-no-data-generating-distribution%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/ezwccqtzOcVOEsiz4Cc-7wjcaMEIvDTdtxP-ih_TSq8=435
summary: There is no data-generating distribution (8 minute read) The data-generating distribution is a convenient mnemonic crutch for machine learning engineers. However, it isn't necessary for understanding machine learning. The same methods are used regardless of whether the world is producing randomness. We need to figure out when we actually need statistical models of data.

title: AlphaEvolve on Google Cloud: AI for agentic discovery and optimization
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcloud.google.com%2Fblog%2Fproducts%2Fai-machine-learning%2Falphaevolve-on-google-cloud%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/YD2LJzab2DMMjEEcSAALmT9rHD94uOlg1C2e7SE3d58=435
summary: AlphaEvolve on Google Cloud: AI for agentic discovery and optimization (4 minute read) AlphaEvolve, now on Google Cloud in private preview, leverages Gemini models to optimize complex problems by evolving algorithms through mutation and evaluation. The technology has improved data center efficiency, reduced Gemini's training time, and accelerated TPU design at Google. Various industries, including biotech and logistics, can use it to solve proprietary optimization challenges.

title: Reference-to-Video Generation
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Ffranciszzj.github.io%2FSaber%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/sWxgYu0o2vPscOiF9wBhT3DhDwkabPHLkpiWRCeTESk=435
summary: Reference-to-Video Generation (4 minute read) Saber is a zero-shot video generation framework that creates identity-consistent videos from reference images and text prompts, trained only on video-text pairs. It avoids costly triplet data by using masked video frames and custom attention to learn identity features.

title: Reasoning with Sampling: Your Base Model is Smarter Than You Think
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Farxiv.org%2Fhtml%2F2510.14901%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b08a0d363-13b01862-7b7f-4091-8d0a-a18507b5d782-000000/RuKBwgHgfsL4bNA5bGaqd8o_EqmCW9ljuxQ4zPmUixg=435
summary: Reasoning with Sampling: Your Base Model is Smarter Than You Think (18 minute read) Reasoning skills unlocked by reinforcement learning may already exist in base models. Harvard researchers propose "power sampling," which biases generation toward tokens with high-likelihood completions rather than tokens with many mediocre completions.

summary: The Art Behind Better AI: How We Achieved a 46% Speed Boost and 23× Cost Reduction (5 minute read) Wix boosted its AI scheduling assistant by adding a deterministic context-engineering pipeline that normalizes inputs, ranks contacts by interaction history, and cuts tokens by 96% with concise formatting. title: Apache Hudi 1.1 Deep Dive: Optimizing Streaming Ingestion with Apache Flink
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhudi.apache.org%2Fblog%2F2025%2F12%2F10%2Fapache-hudi-11-deep-dive-optimizing-streaming-ingestion-with-flink%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b0d189ec2-3866eb1e-7402-47a9-94e1-f43aca7361c5-000000/P4wfooae8ctc9H-Lct1SV4Ey_fU-JZvXgQwsoeIalh8=435
summary: Apache Hudi 1.1 Deep Dive: Optimizing Streaming Ingestion with Apache Flink (5 minute read) Apache Hudi 1.1 delivers major streaming ingestion performance gains for petabyte-scale workloads by optimizing Flink integration, reducing SerDe overhead, and eliminating record-level byte copying. Benchmarks show up to 25% throughput improvements and significant reductions in latency and GC pressure, especially with string-heavy schemas. These enhancements are fully backward-compatible.

title: Apache Spark Optimizations
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 23 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FuwfNEe/1/0100019b0d189ec2-3866eb1e-7402-47a9-94e1-f43aca7361c5-000000/-IhDNvF6uXJGTf6hf-Vc13Pf7Yp8KA07DZ2IBWlvIOY=435
summary: Apache Spark Optimizations (23 minute read) Flipkart slashed a 35+ hour Spark ETL job on 7TB of data by 36% to 20–22 hours using repartitioning, high parallelism, AQE skew handling, Kryo+Snappy compression, off-heap memory, dynamic allocation, and smart caching/checkpointing. The optimizations eliminated spills, OOMs, stragglers, and excessive shuffle I/O while dramatically improving cluster efficiency.

title: Improving MySQL Cluster Uptime: Making MGR Viable at Scale
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.uber.com%2Fblog%2Fimproving-mysql-cluster-uptime-part2%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b0d189ec2-3866eb1e-7402-47a9-94e1-f43aca7361c5-000000/KzjG9OE8I5Ax47O_pegnOUg5k1qn-dl1g8lvLOWQKWU=435
summary: Improving MySQL Cluster Uptime: Making MGR Viable at Scale (8 minute read) Uber replaced manual, error-prone MySQL failovers with MySQL Group Replication using a 3-node single-primary consensus group plus async read replicas, backed by a custom orchestrator for automated onboarding, rebalancing, and recovery. This delivered near-instant automatic failovers, strict consistency, zero split-brain risk, and drastically reduced downtime with only minor performance overhead at massive scale.

title: You Gotta Push If You Wanna Pull
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.morling.dev%2Fblog%2Fyou-gotta-push-if-you-wanna-pull%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019b0d189ec2-3866eb1e-7402-47a9-94e1-f43aca7361c5-000000/uk653RJAr-u7Pyi87rfbeqqccKFohR9iKbp_wNJKTyM=435
summary: You Gotta Push If You Wanna Pull (5 minute read) Efficient “pull” queries that feel instant require precomputed materialized views that handle performance, joins, and the exact data shape the application needs. These views stay fresh in real time by continuously pushing only incremental changes from the source (via CDC tools like Debezium + Flink, or modern IVM systems like Materialize and pg_ivm), delivering the best of both worlds: zero recomputation cost and immediate results on every pull.

title: Should CSS be Constraints?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 17 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fpavpanchekha.com%2Fblog%2Fwhy-css-bad.html%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b0d276ee8-65d184dd-2edc-4a0d-ae71-40cdb142379f-000000/XDygsUmf_7zHxiJF4kYpu1yWNIno4CpbH8rgp5tMf3k=435
summary: Should CSS be Constraints? (17 minute read) CSS is hard, and the rules can be quite complex. It is currently hard to predict what CSS will result in. One commonly-proposed replacement for CSS is a constraint system. However, with constraint-based systems, it is possible to have more than or less than one layout that satisfies the rules. Predictability suffers again once you have complicated constraints and conflict handling rules.

summary: HTTPS certificate industry phasing out less secure domain validation methods (4 minute read) Chrome Root Program and CA/Browser Forum adopted Ballots SC-080, SC-090, and SC-091 to sunset 11 legacy Domain Control Validation methods relying on email, phone, fax, postal mail, and reverse DNS lookups by March 2028, pushing Certificate Authorities toward automated, cryptographically verifiable ACME-based validation to prevent fraudulent certificate issuance.

The system uses four layers: ephemeral session metadata (device, location, and usage patterns), long-term facts stored via a dedicated tool, lightweight summaries of recent messages, and a sliding window of the current conversation. OpenAI prioritizes speed and token efficiency over detailed historical context.

title: Is It a Bubble?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 58 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.oaktreecapital.com%2Finsights%2Fmemo%2Fis-it-a-bubble%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b0de2e5a4-ecea8ec4-4b82-4da4-8b49-a2b541c02ce3-000000/lQQcLWUyeiFRDMvR7Eb0gkIOPmOH-wVq3Bmo1gTpv_M=435
summary: Is It a Bubble? (58 minute read) No one can definitively say whether we are currently in a bubble or not. No one should go all-in without acknowledging that they face the risk of ruin if things go badly. At the same time, no one should stay all-out and risk missing out on one of the great technological steps forward. A moderate position seems like the best approach. Intelligent investment requires sober, insightful judgment and skillful implementation.

title: Vectorized MAXSCORE over WAND: building faster text search for humans and agents
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-11, Reading time: 19 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fturbopuffer.com%2Fblog%2Ffts-v2-maxscore%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b0de2e5a4-ecea8ec4-4b82-4da4-8b49-a2b541c02ce3-000000/fm3MBlBGDlrf544idTegyrlxsSPi_aVTBmPJw2mlUrg=435
summary: Vectorized MAXSCORE over WAND: building faster text search for humans and agents (19 minute read) Designing fast search engines is a subtle optimization problem. It takes effort to select the right algorithm and then tune it to get the best out of the CPU. Agents write longer queries than humans, so it is becoming increasingly important for text search to scale well with the number of terms. For text search, this means the cursor has shifted more and more from WAND to MAXSCORE.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-12, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Farstechnica.com%2Finformation-technology%2F2025%2F12%2Fopenai-releases-gpt-5-2-after-code-red-google-threat-alert%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b124d24c9-10fe77b1-bfbe-4cb1-a24a-bf7d6a429171-000000/BNiALrxOKsTmqOffX6GnEuIz3v7HKqH2F8Jrk9kahZQ=435
summary: OpenAI releases GPT-5.2 after “code red” Google threat alert (6 minute read) GPT-5.2 has been released in three variants: Instant, Thinking, and Pro. 5.2 is designed to unlock more economic value for people. It features a 400,000-token context window and a knowledge cutoff date of August 31. GPT-5.1 will remain available in ChatGPT for paid users for three months. GPT-5.2 is OpenAI's third major model release since August.
